utterances: Stay with us on DAY TO DAY from NPR News.
Melania Trump has raised the profile of her homeland, Slovenia.
Her new role as first lady has even helped increase tourism there.
And as Joanna Kakissis reports, the country is cashing in.
(SOUNDBITE OF BELL)
The hamlet of Sevnica, population 5,000, sits right in the middle of Slovenia on a green valley along the Sava River surrounded by hills covered in pine forest.
It's really amazing climate.
And the food is great to enjoy.
You should try our wine, our salami.
We have great things to try.
That's Lidija Ogorevc, a guide here.
She's giving us a town tour focused on Melanija Knavs, the birth name of Melania Trump.

We pass her elementary school, the factory where her mom used to make children's clothes, the communist-era apartment block where she first lived and the neighborhood where her parents own a big house.
Do you see the houses there?
OK, that's Beverly Hills of Sevnica.
The Beverly Hills of...
I say it like that because most people that had money could afford a house to build there.
She takes us to cafes offering Melania cakes and first lady apple pies and a shoe store selling White House slippers.

Demand for these tours has gone up 30 percent since the beginning of the year, which is something for a town that until last year was known mostly for its underwear factory and salami festival, says Mayor Srecko Ocvirk.
(SOUNDBITE OF ACCORDION MUSIC)
I meet the mayor at Sevnica's castle, which dates to the early Middle Ages, and where an accordionist in lederhosen serenades a wedding party.
(Through interpreter) Melania was raised here.
She used to be our neighbor.
That's what we focus on.
Yes, she's President Trump's wife and that's what she's known for, but we want to focus only on her.
The castle sells first lady wine, chocolate, salami, tea cups and even face cream.
Melanija Knavs left Slovenia in the 1990s to pursue fashion modeling.
She is not known to have visited in more than a decade.
The first lady hired Natasa Pirc Musar's law firm last year to protect her reputation.
Musar makes sure her photo and full name are not used in Melania-themed products and that they are appropriate.
We would probably react heavily if somebody is going to make an underwear named Melania Trump (laughter).
She is a tolerant lady.
She knows how to draw a line, where the border is, we discuss this.
And until now, the reaction was not needed in a single case.
People in Sevnica gush about Melania Trump, but not everyone in Slovenia feels the same way about her husband.
Hello there.
Hello, hello.
How are you?
I'm Joanna, nice to meet you.
Good, good.
I meet Ivo Vajgl, a member of the European Parliament, at his home outside Ljubljana, the capital.
He says he's put off by President Trump's coziness with authoritarians and populists and his poor treatment of longtime allies in Europe.
That stance was embraced this week by the non-partisan League of Women Voters.
The League is a social welfare group itself.
The Iraqi army's first foray into the oil port of Basra in March was widely perceived as hasty and ill-planned.
But with American military help, Nouri al-Maliki's troops eventually prevailed.

They quickly followed up with an offensive against Mahdi Army militia fighters in Sadr City, a Baghdad neighborhood of more than two million people that's largely been out of government control for the past five years.
He made a good step, Maliki, we were always asking him to do.
He went against the militias.
And he went further than the Shiite militias.
Mahmoud Othman is a Kurdish member of parliament who says Maliki made a wise calculation.
As a Shiite Muslim, Maliki was seen as beholden to Shiite parties.
Had he not attacked the Shiite militias first, Othman says, the prime minister would have been perceived as another sectarian protecting his own.
It was only after the actions against fellow Shiite's that Maliki turned his attention to al-Qaida and other militant Sunni groups in the northern city of Mosul.
The surge in popularity is a turnaround for Maliki, who'd been roundly criticize as weak, ineffective and dependent on partisan interests.
But he has yet to prove his effectiveness in his own government.
This is Wamidh Nadhmi, a political science professor at Baghdad University.
Half of the cabinet have now resigned.
And Maliki is doing nothing either to bring technocrats or to bring people from the other political parties.
Nadhmi points out that although Maliki's political bloc won more votes than any other group in the 2005 election, it wasn't enough to gain a majority in parliament.
So he's dependent on other parties in his coalition.
To make matters worse, Nadhmi says, Maliki's Dawa Party is deeply divided, meaning the prime minister must also keep them happy by handing out ministerial jobs, regardless of competence.
While many Iraqi politicians, though, decry what they say is incompetence and corruption in Maliki's government, they still want their share of the political pie.
Dr.
Ayad al-Samaraie is head of the Iraqi Islamic Party, which is part of the biggest Sunni bloc in parliament.
His bloc left Maliki's coalition last year and is now negotiating to get back.
What does Samaraie want in return for his support?
Some posts in the cabinet.
If we are going to share or join the cabinet, then obviously we have the right to nominate the people who are to fulfill those positions
Not everyone believes that Maliki's military successes have earned him popular support.
(Through translator) There were human rights violations in Basra.
Many people were killed and wounded in the bloodshed.
Kamal Fouzi is a member of parliament, loyal to anti-American cleric Muqtada al-Sadr, whose militia was the main target of Iraqi army operations in Basra and Sadr City.
He says Shiites bore the brunt of the attacks, while Sunni insurgent leaders in Mosul were allowed to slip away before the army moved in.
Fouzi says Maliki's party will suffer for it in provincial elections that are tentatively set for this fall.
In central Baghdad, where security is better and business is brisk, attitudes towards Maliki are mixed.
This is Hisham Ahkmed(ph), a 30-year-old businessman.
(Through translator) My opinion about Maliki is different now, especially after the military operations in Basra, Sadr city and Mosul.
I think security is about 70 percent better now and his position is stronger.
Ahkmed says if things getting better, he might vote for Maliki's party.
Ali Sal(ph), a 45-year-old Army officer is less optimistic.
He says he thinks Maliki was right to take military action, but that militias of all stripes remained a major problem.
(Trough translator) We have Kurdish militias, Shiite militias and Sunni militias as well as other that work undercover of religion or anything else.
And they're supported by the government.
Sal says he doesn't support any politicians.
In his words, they're all losers.
Corey Flintoff, NPR News, Baghdad.
Time now for another turkey tale.
(Soundbite of phone ringing)
Good morning, Meat and Poultry Hotline.
How may I help you?
I need a question answered, please.
Yes.
I would...
I'm Kathy Bernard, and I've been here on the hotline 15 and a half years.
I had one - it was yesterday - and the woman, she had a bird that had two necks in it, and she called very disturbed, thinking that the bird was actually a two-necked bird when it was alive.
But you know, this can happen because, you know, the giblets and the necks aren't necessarily with the turkey that they're from.
The processing plants try to get one per bird, but sometimes two necks just got put in the bird.
That's all.
But she was, oh, my gosh, you know, I think this bird may have had two heads.
But that's not the case.
The staffers at the Turkey Hotline tell us they have to take every question seriously.
It's a matter of food safety.
After 18 years and nearly 150,000 lives lost, the United States seemed closer than ever to ending the war in Afghanistan after months of negotiations with the Taliban.
But then, in a tweet, President Trump called this off.
Yeah.
President Trump said he was canceling a planned summit with Afghanistan's president, Ashraf Ghani, and leaders of the Taliban.
And it was supposed to have happened yesterday at Camp David, just days before the anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks.
NPR's Diaa Hadid has been following all of this.
She's based in Pakistan and joins us.
Hi there, Diaa.
Good morning.
